name: Asenapine (Saphris)
summary: Atypical antipsychotic used for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, notable for its sublingual or transdermal administration routes.
description: Asenapine is an atypical antipsychotic approved for the treatment of schizophrenia in adults and for acute treatment of manic or mixed episodes associated with bipolar I disorder in adults and pediatric patients aged 10–17 years. It has high affinity for multiple serotonin, dopamine, alpha-adrenergic, and histamine receptors, and is administered sublingually or via transdermal patch to avoid extensive first-pass metabolism.

items: Acute manic or mixed episodes in bipolar I disorder (adults, pediatric patients 10–17 years)

sections.text: Antagonizes multiple receptors, including serotonin 5-HT2A, dopamine D2, alpha-adrenergic, and histamine H1, leading to antipsychotic and mood-stabilizing effects.

adult.start: Schizophrenia: 5 mg sublingually twice daily; Bipolar mania: 10 mg sublingually twice daily
adult.titrate: Adjust based on clinical response and tolerability

sections.pediatric: Bipolar mania (10–17 years): start 2.5–5 mg twice daily; adjust to 10 mg twice daily as tolerated

sections.text: Onset of antimanic effect may be seen within days; full antipsychotic response may take several weeks.

sections.black_box: Increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis.
other: Avoid eating or drinking for 10 minutes after sublingual dose

items.risk: Increased risk of EPS and metabolic effects

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; neonatal EPS or withdrawal possible
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.pediatrics: Approved for bipolar mania in ages 10–17; safety for schizophrenia not established
sections.geriatrics: Monitor for orthostatic hypotension and sedation

sections.text: Gradual tapering recommended to minimize withdrawal or relapse risk.

items: Sublingual route bypasses first-pass metabolism; swallowing tablets reduces bioavailability.
Transdermal formulation may benefit patients with adherence or swallowing issues.
Lower metabolic risk compared to some other atypicals.
